I own quite a few Polka food storage boxes. They've been sold at very reasonable prices in their millions by Asda, Tesco etc. They have very good well-fitting lids. But whenever I took something like soup to work, I'd be afraid of the mess caused by leakages from the lid popping open. So I designed these clips to hold the lids on. They work brilliantly!
I've created an extra secure version which also achieved its purpose very well, but is much harder to remove.
And so you don't have to print one at a time, I've included a 4-up version.
If you want to 100% secure a larger box like the 1.8l version I've pictured here, consider using 6 or 8 clips.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

Full

Notes: I printed mine in PLA on an M3D Micro

1. Measurements I measured using a vernier caliper 2. Design In Tinkercad I used two nested curved roof objects, one as a hole, a rectangular hole to truncate the curve, a rectangle for the spine, another curved roof for the bottom end, and a wedge for the hook which goes over the box flange. 3. Test Print, Refinement, Reprint The first print went well, but my clip was too narrow and a little on the short side, so I elongated the entire thing by a factor of 1.1 and made it double the depth. Then it was perfect. Finally I created the extra secure version by lengthening the hook part by 0.1mm, and created a 4-up version by tesselation.

title: Loadmaster shell slider for .223/5.56 REMIX
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Like a lot of others that use the LEE PRO 1000 loader, I had issues with the case feeder double feeding cases, so I researched possible fixes. To remedy this on my press, I added a small wooden block on to the factory slider/feeder. And it worked better, but it still occasionly missfed.
I then in one of the many instructional videos on YouTube for this press, I saw one where the poster had printed out a part similar to this. SO, i started looking thru thingiverse and grabcad for a part file.
Thankfully I found the original file, and modified it slightly to make it as tall as my OEM part with the added height that the wooden block provided. Thanks to the original poster for taking the time to make this part, which allowed me to easily modify to meet my personal requirements.
As such, I wanted to share my revised version in case anyone else was interested in such a part for their LEE PRO 1000 reloading machine.

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

Notes: PLA @ 180 and HEATBED @ 70 on my printrbot style REPRAP.
I use marlin firmware on my bot, and slic3r to generate the gcode file, which I print from SD at the bot. I printed this and it fit just fine, I did have to do some cleanup, but it was negligible. I will post pics of the part on the press soon.

description.text: We made this just fooling around with our glass cutter and decided a Wine glass from a Bottle top would be pretty interesting. Printed with Simplify3D See instructions below for details. We used this bottle Glass cutter: (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00ZMPZ23S?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00) works pretty good even though you have to fig-it with the settings a bit. It appears to be home made, painted by hand then sold on Amazon,

Process Used for Bottle Cut Wine Bottle using a bottle cutter.
Use sand paper starting with 220 Grit
Sand until smooth and all uneven surfaces are flat.
Next use 320 grit, 400 grit to smooth the edge of the glass and make it more like a proper wine glass.
Place the wine bottle cork into the glass from the top and push in leaving 1" at the bottom for the printed base.
3D Print this base and push into the I.D. of the bottle opening. Print should be firm, if it is not then you may need to make the diameter a little larger. (Not all are the same size, I had to reprint as well to get a snug / tight fit.
Enjoy!

Nine different little low poly pumpkins ready to be printed for Halloween. Included are: Chompy, Slurpy, Crushy, Piercy, Slicey, Crunchy, Munchy, Smoochy and Squashy They print quick without any support. They can be stacked by snapping them together. title: Quick Fit (Richrap Compatable) X Cariage For Orca (0.3)

description.text:
This is a replacement X carriage for the Orca 0.3 (it may work for the 0.2 or 0.4, I dont have those machines so its not tested there). It is printed in 4 parts and is screwd together with M4 studding.  
I have included the fan mount and blower duct that I am currently using.  
Not all of richraps extruders derivatives will work as the hole size is constrained by the X bar spacing in the oposite direction to the original.  
The source is in Alibre (Ive not given up openSCAD, but I need a more flexible design tool), sorry I don't have the capabilty to export it to anything but .stl  
**The latch is Richrap's origional duplicated here for completeness

All printed parts
LM8UU x 4
M4 Studding x 240mm x 2
M4 Nylock x 9
M4 Washer x 12
624ZZ x 1
M4 x 20 cap screw x 5

Hello, this is a very simple bouncer for Metz Mecablitz AF 58. It fits without any hard to print mechanism to the flash-head. The light is published very soft in all directions. I made it to shoot photos indoor at lower light. So the light is reflected by walls and top of the room and the shadows are much softer. To print i used ABS (natural) without support at 100 % Infill at 0.2mm layer height.
On the Top, the sphere has a few small holes, but i think that does`nt matter.
The Sphere has a diameter of 100 mm; Have fun... I would be happy about feedback. Update 15th Oct., 2015:
I added Version 1.1. In this version, the top wall of the Sphere has is flat. So the wall has about 3mm thickness. I hope the bridging is better now. German description: Hallo, dies ist ein sehr einfacher Bouncer für den Metz Mecablitz 58. Er passt ohne kompliziert zu druckende Haltemechanismen auf den Kopf des Blitzgerätes.
Das Licht wird sehr weich in alle Richtungen geleitet, so dass er für Blitzlichaufnahmen in geschlossenen Räumen eingesetzt werden kann. Das Licht wird dann von den Wänden und der Decke reflektiert, was zu weicherem Schatten und gleichmässigerer Ausleuchtung führt. Ich habe ihn aus ABS (transparent) mit 0,2mm Schichtdicke, 1mm Wandstärke, ohne Support mit 100% Infill gedruckt. Oben befinden sich druckbedingt ein paar kleine Löcher, die m.E. aber kein Problem sind. Der Durchmesser der Kugel beträgt 100mm. So, habt Spass damit... Würde mich über Anregungen freuen. Update am 15.10.2015:
Version 1.1 hinzugefügt. In dieser Version, befindet sich eine Fläche an der oberen Stelle der Kugel. Dort ist die Wandung nun 3mm stark. Ich hoffe so lässt sich die Kegel besser drucken (ohne Infill) Horex1200

title: Samsung Galaxy S1 Clock radio stand

description.text:
Samsung Galaxy S1 Clock stand.
I use my old Galaxy S1 as an alarm clock in the bedroom. I needed a nice dock but couldn't find one I liked online.
The dock has holes for charging the phone whilst in the stand and has notches for the buttons no matter which way round the phone is.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

0.2

Notes: Printed in white PLA. 0.2 mm layer height, 0.2 infill. Used 3 outer layers, 2 bottom layers and 4 top layers.
It's a very tight fit but the phone snaps into the holder nicely, the charging cable fits well. I orientated mine with volume buttons at the top.
There was a bit of warping at the base but not too much. If i printed this again I would reduce the outer shells to 2 shells and the infill to 0.1% to try and reduce the build time and reduce warping. You might want to scale it at 105% to give you a bit of extra room for the phone.

comments.author: bmoshe

comments.text:
Not sure where the animosity is coming from but I am more than glad to share my source material with you and how I made the sculpt. It was a class project a few years ago when I was in grad school. I and about a dozen other students had to create a yoda bust for a mock Bioware test. I started with a low resolution cage and sculpted from there. Ultimately I took the sculpt and retopologized it so that I could create a game resolution asset for a pretend Star Wars game. You can see my progress on it on my portfolio site. I can also send you contacts of the people who were working with me at the time that I was making this sculpt. I do not mind sharing my work.
http://barakmoshe.weebly.com/3d.htmlhttp://barakmoshe.weebly.com/3...
This was a post I did on my site on how my sculpt came to be along with some variations of it in zbrush
http://barakmoshe.blogspot.com/2013/08/yoda-alert-origin-story-of-yoda-sculpt.htmlhttp://barakmoshe.blogspot.com...
Here are some other artists in my class who did the assignment with me and their version of their yoda is in there too:
http://marlowerosenbaum.weebly.com/http://marlowerosenbaum.weebly...
http://mbakermanart.weebly.com/personal-work.htmlhttp://mbakermanart.weebly.com...
http://priscillalanderer.weebly.com/http://priscillalanderer.weebl...
I agree that this is a licensed product which is why I don't sell it but I do not understand why you're accusing me of copying another mesh. There are plenty of yoda meshes out there like you suggested. This one happens to be mine. I can give credit to Frank Oz, Stuart Freeborn and Henson as well as the rest of the team who designed the original Yoda puppet. I used photographs of that one as my primary reference for sculpting.
I would like to see which model you are talking about and I would like to compare it to my work. I can tell you for a fact that I worked on my model from the ground up. I can tell you this because I have a know of former classmates who watched me do it.
I don't mind the accusation that you're throwing my way. I just want to present this to you so you can understand how this particular Yoda was made.
-Thank you!
comments.author: Geoffro

comments.text: The animosity wasn't directed at you personally, I apologize, it's directed at the people that do claim others work and profiteer of it. It is clear you created this mesh, it's insane the striking resemblance to the other ones on here - I vowed not to spend any more time going through all these ripped meshes, I'm sure you can find them you sound intelligent enough. if you did create it it shouldn't be hard for you to find a knock off I guess.
comments.author: bmoshe

comments.text:
No worries :)
If it helps at all, this upload of this particular Yoda sculpt does happen to be the first one on Thingiverse. A lot of the others that you see are derivatives of this one. I am acutely aware of how this guy took off over the years. You can check my blog for the section that I dedicated to all of the places that it has reached.
http://barakmoshe.blogspot.com/search/label/Yoda%20Alert%21http://barakmoshe.blogspot.com...
In Siggraph 2011, Makerbot had a booth and offered to print models for free if you gave them an obj file. I asked them if they could print my school project and they agreed. They really liked the results and asked me if I had heard of Thingiverse. They urged me to set up an account and upload this Yoda and then they helped me do it at the booth. It took off from there and I kinda just left it alone and watched it grow. That's why this is the only thing I uploaded to Thingiverse. That's also why it's such a big file and people had to make decimated versions of it. In fact the first successful derivative of this sculpt was a light version of it. I could post some of my other sculptures but I doubt they would be as fun to print as this one. I don't have a 3D printer myself so I don't have any personal projects to share like everyone else does on this site. I'm just glad other people with printers can print this model for their own enjoyment. I do still have my original print from Siggraph at my desk which is nice :) (Zcorp print too! Very nice quality)
I personally love watching everyone tweak and morph this model, making it their own. I find it really flattering that they like my model enough to do it. Again I wasn't expecting my work to be received this way so it's all very new to me. I respect your concern as it can get frustrating to see people take credit and make money off of other people's work. For me, this was a passion project and I have no problem sharing it. I also have no problem proving that I made this particular Yoda model in case there is any confusion as there are a lot of other models like it on the internet. As long as I don't make money off of it which I don't intend to, I don't imagine having to deal with lawsuits from Disney personally. If I get a cease and desist which I've seen people get with some of their models from other companies, I will take my work off of this site. It would be unfortunate of course but I would have to respect the people who actually do own the intellectual property.

comments.text: Full res is nice if someone has a large printer like a reprap or wants to use the mesh for something specific, but most people with Makerbots are only going to print it about 3 or 4 inches tall so 50K or less should be good. I reduced it to print to about 45K and it printed with minimal noticable facets. I'd be interested in hearing how the model was made. Was it scanned or modeled?  How was it done and what software? And lastly do you have other designs? Thanks for a great model.
comments.author: bmoshe

comments.text: The model was sculpted in zbrush. I used picture references from episode 5 to get it down. It was decimated a little and exported as an obj file. I have more stuff lying around but they're kinda complex and most likely won't print well. I'm working on a couple of new busts at the moment. I put yoda out because it seemed like the friendliest sculpt for printing. If these current projects look good and have the potential to work, I'll upload them later.

This is a clock winding key made for an antique clock manufactured 1920. This has an opening of about 3.69mm and is tapered to 3.19mm to fit the shaft correctly.
Printing this is quite simple, just print it the way it orients. With they keyhole up and it prints perfectly. No rafts or supports are needed, which is why I designed it this way.
If you need one with larger holes for different sized clocks, let me know ill be more than happy to accommodate them!

This is a simple manipulative that shows how the Pythagorean Theorem can be proven using rearrangement. We start with a tray that has a fixed internal area equal to (a+b)2 and four identical triangles with sides a, b and c. If we arrange the triangles around the perimeter of the tray as shown in figure one the negative space (space not occupied by the triangles) is a square with sides of length c. When we rearrange the triangles to form the rectangles as shown in figure two the negative space is split between two squares, one with sides of length "a" and a second with sides of length "b". Because the negative space does not change this proves a2 + b2 = c2. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8ba9Bfx64fZ

title: Fan Mount for CTC & Makerbot Replicator Clones

description.text:
There is no cooling fan on the CTC by default, which is problematic for PLA... I had a big power supply fan so I just build this one You can put on the front, the left and the right this fan mount
You just need 4 Screws + Bolts to mount it
2 of them are for adjusting the height On the photos, I have some duck tape in order to test different cases.
On the benchmark, there is a bed levelling issue and I switch on the fan from the start (so warping...)
The result is not terrific but it will improve.
Bridges that are behind the fan are even much better. Second test, I put the fan on the left and the bed was levelled.
The distance is a bit longer, it helps to distribute a bit more the air, little improvement on the result
A second fan is needed in the right side too

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20% at least

Notes: Less than 5 hours with 60/100 mm/sec

I needed a round lid with a hex pattern in it. I have previously published a parametric square pattern that i coded in scad. You can find it here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:476127. Rather than just dumping the square pattern in an stl file and cutting it in FreeCAD, I decided to code a new version of the pattern with a nice round border. Open the Customizer and enter your specific parameters to create your own round pattern.

Inspired by: http://alt-fractals.blogspot.nl/2011/04/impossible-snowflake.html
The half version is more suitable for printing. Also, it is more hollow on the inside.
Update: made one with 1 iteration more by printing the small one 18 times and glueing them together with acetone.

I tried to print this thing without having a second thought. Forgot about the overhang which was too big. The base also has very little area to stick to the bed, so after printing 3/4 mine got loose and I had to stop it. The result is still amusing though :-)
Update: the half one prints more or less fine with small overhang problems.

After building a new printer, I needed to calibrate retraction.  I found, however, that current methods provided little help.  Every calibration object I found had issues.  I eventually decided that I would need to create my own calibration part.  Towards that end, I came up with the following list of what I think makes a good retract calibration object:
1)  As much as possible, a good retract calibration object should only test retraction.  It should be mostly independent of other calibrations, and therefore easy to print.  Many retract calibration objects require that printers be well calibrated for numerous other parameters.  Some test retraction, but also depend on cooling, overhang, Z registration, extrusion flow rate, and other things.  That not only makes the object hard to print, it also makes it difficult to say how well retraction is working.  For example, cooling problems might result in pulling strings of molten plastic - that might look like a retraction problem where none exists. 
2)  It should be clear where retract and reload occurred on the calibration object, and what the travel was between them.  Many retract calibration objects visually look like they will provide this, but fail in reality.  When the GCODE is visualized, the extrusion path is complex.  Retracts do not take place where expected, and travel after retract does not go where one would think. This makes it very hard to tell under what circumstances retraction is working.
3)  The retract calibration object should give quantitative results.  Many current objects give nothing more than a qualitative result.  Although there is an indication that retraction is working to some extent, there is rarely an indication of the limits of that extent. 
4)  Printing the calibration object should not take much time or filament.  Many current objects print much more than needed to evaluate retraction. 
5)  Ideally, it should be possible to customize the calibration object to better suit specific printer needs.  
After a number of failed attempts at designing a good test object, this calibration part is the one I have settled on.  For me, it meets all of the above requirements.  The print is very easy and forgiving, and gives a clear indication of how retract is working for specific gap sizes.  I have already made big improvements using this object, and expect to make more. 
The OpenSCAD source is included with parameters to make customization easy should you need different settings from the ones I used in producing the included STL files.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: Set the extrusion width to 0.65mm so that the fin sections are a single width wide. If 0.65mm is not reasonable for your printer, use the OpenSCAD file and adjust the parameters to a width that works for you. Plate multiple of these at the same time so that cooling is not an issue. I generally plate all of the small gaps (1mm-5mm) as one print, and then plate all of the large gaps (10mm, 20mm, 30mm, 40mm) as a second print. That seems to work pretty well. Print settings should be very forgiving. One of my main goals was for this to be able to be printed even if a lot is off on a printer. It does need some basic printing ability, but the exact settings should not be that important. I recommend watching the print to make sure that:
1) The retract is happening on the side marked retract (indented in base) and reloading on the side marked reload (bump in base). If this is not the case, either use the OpenSCAD file to flip those markers (there is a parameter to do it), or just be aware which side is which.
2) The travel is as expected. On any given part, a line of one fin should print, retract should take place, the print head should move directly across the gap, reload should take place, and then the second fin should print. Sometimes slicers do odd things. I have tried to force the behavior on this object, but your mileage might vary - so verify this is giving you useful information. If the print order is not correct, your slicer might have an option to print each plated object individually, and that might resolve the issue.
3) The retract and reload should not be doing anything visually odd. When I started working on retraction, I found the print head would sit for far too long at the retract and reload points. That was useful calibration information by itself. I find the large gaps are most appropriate for determining the best retract length. I look for the smallest amount that will make all gaps come out clean. More than necessary is not beneficial, so try to find the point where results are not good enough and then increase the retract just a little. I find the small gaps are better for things like speed, temperature, and minimum travel after retract.

comments.text: BTW - The pictures attached to this thing are showing the large gap set for my current retraction (2.7mm), small gap set for the same, and my original small gap settings where anything less than 3mm was sealed closed by stringing filament.  The blobs that are visible in the final prints are only on the base section and are a result of overextruding in a 100% infill and then dragging the excess out - rather than anything to do with retraction.  You can see this by looking at the actual fins - though fine details are a bit hard to see in the photos.  Those are completely clean at this point.
comments.author: orgemd

ENGLISH:
A set of parts suitable for the standard X-axis carriage for mounting an automatic leveling table. No problem is mounted on the carriage unmodified. It requires servo drive MG90S or similar in size, as well as any available limit switch.

РУССКИЙ:
Набор деталей, подходящий под стандартную каретку оси X для монтажа системы автоматического выравнивания уровня стола. Без проблем монтируется на немодифицированную каретку. Требует серво-привод MG90S или аналог по габаритам, а так же любой доступный концевой переключатель.

IMPORTANT: Separate all of the pieces in your slicer, scale up 20x. V2 Includes a pin, if that doesn't work PM me and I will see about fixing it. Twisty Puzzle Museum Entry: http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pkey=5644 Stickers are available at http://oliverstickers.com/stickers-for-3d-printed-puzzles/ryan-beam NEW VIDEO + PROTOTYPES: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bVbP9QI4sDQ
Video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hlZFYVeFIGg This puzzle applies the "bump" modification to the 1x2x3. A bump modification is when you cut off part of one side of a puzzle, then compensate for what you removed by adding that much on the opposite side. This continues until all 6 sides have been modified. I was surprised that this actually took longer than 5 seconds to solve. Since there are no colors, trying to solve by shape causes an odd parity. I was inspired by tallpawn's bump Jing's Pyraminx, here's a link: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:991897 UPDATED VERSION 2: Better than the last one, includes center cap+ improved turning quality.

title: faster sqrt function for marlin in planner.ccp

description.text:
float SqrtAprox(float number) {//low in fat
unsigned long i;
float x, y;
y = number;
i = ( long ) &y;
i = 0x5f375a86 - ( i >> 1 );
y = ( float ) &i;
return number * y;
} This is an alternate planner.ccp file that has a faster sqrt calc function. I don't know if it really speeds up planner.ccp but it does increase the performance of a sqrt to complete by 300%. read here for more info http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?147,219210 I read about several methods before hacking this one together. I do not claim where it comes from just that it was from researching different methods. several people are likely to credit as it is based of of the quake III engine hacks to speed up lighting calculations, and all i did was slim it down some and test its performance, then modified the planner.ccp file. it is still experimental and has some errors that are around up to 3.5% for integers. I'll play around with reducing those errors. this is ok for planner.ccp as it does not use the calc for distance. Just replace marlin firmware with this file The goal is to free up processing power on arduino during acceleration, so i can do detail graphics with lcd in near future. image included shows a side by side compare with new vs old plannner.ccp file

replace marlin planner.ccp file   
this is experimetal.

comments.text: I'm trying it right now. Put this after the includes in planner.cpp:
comments.author: avion23

comments.text: you may be right.  John Carmack doesn't take any credit.  this is what it is. an optimization for sqrt. data supports the speed improvement. The gains in sqrt calc are substantial.
comments.author: jamesvilleneuve

comments.text: I don't doubt that your gains are real and substantial.  After all, we used that sqrt optimization, albeit briefly, in Sailfish (back then it was the Jetty Firmware) and timed it.  It was definitely a time saver and we used it until we found an even better approach: reducing the precision of the calcs and getting an additional speed boost.  About the same time, we reworked some of the math to be in v^2 space thus eliminating one or two square roots.  (There may also still be an unneeded one in Marlin around the XY jerk calc?  I don't recall.)  Then later, to get even more performance we went to fixed point math.  What you're now seeing in Sailfish is many iterations later and the fixed point does make some of the code a little opaque.
comments.author: jamesvilleneuve

comments.text: And, fwiw, that algorithm is based upon John Carmack's fast inverse square root.  Sailfish uses a different approach which yields a 5x speed up in the square root vs. libavr's square root.
comments.author: dnewman

comments.text: So what approach am I referring to?

author: jamesvilleneuve

description.text: Óculos  FPV

The Hearing Amplifier. 
When it comes to buying a hearing aid, prices are a bit steep. The electronics that go into manufacturing a powered hearing aid are micro-sized, and therefore very expensive. There are no electronics required with set of hearing aids, making them a great alternative to high priced electronic ones. 
These simple hearing aid alternatives are much more eco-friendly than electronic ones. They are fully recyclable and remove the need for expensive and environmentally detrimental batteries.

• The highest possible print resolution is recommended. This will ensure that sound amplification is at a max. The rough and bumpy walls produced by a low resolution print will scatter sound waves and direct less sound into the ear.

  • It is best to print this item with Nylon, but ABS will work very well also. PLA will work, but it will not amplify the sound as well. The reason for printing in Nylon is because it is harder than the other plastics, meaning the amplifier walls will reflect more sound into the ear, rather than absorbing it.
    • -A tip for producing the best seal with the inner ear, is using a spare set of rubber fittings from a pair of in-ear headphones to place on the ends of the hearing amplifier. Likely not all kinds of fittings are going to work, but it is worth a try.
This Item is a work in progress. Please print off a copy and message me about how they fit. I would like to make them as comfortable as possible for everyone.

description.header: Maybe you'd like to carry other tools with your Wave? If so, check out my Modular Leatherman Wave holster instead.

description.text:
• Wave holster (right side carry).stl has a 30° forward tilt when worn on the right side, and a backwards tilt when worn on the left side.
  • Wave holster (left side carry).stl has a 30° forward tilt when worn on the left side, and a backwards tilt when worn on the right side.
  • Wave holster (horizontal belt hole).stl has no tilt.

This Thing is no longer based on the Things listed below. It's now a version of my Modular Leatherman Wave holster, but with the module mounting points removed. The belt loop accepts belts up to 45 mm (1.75 inches) wide. CaptCanadaMan's improvement on babozor318's Leatherman Wave holster (itself a reworking of Adam Savage's Wave holster) was genius in its use of an angled belt loop to make the tool more accessible; if you wear the holster forward enough, you can even access your Wave easily while seated in the car! However, the loop was added to a massive rectangular block on the back of the holster, which was uncomfortable to wear even after softening the edges and corners with a file. And because it was a big block with a 90° overhang it also had to be printed with some support, which was a strange design decision. So I've made the following changes:
  • The belt loop block is now self-supporting with a 30° lead-up.
  • The top of the belt loop has a matching 30° taper so that the holster clears your waist.
  • The top of the holster is shortened and rounded off.
  • I have added two cut-outs in the base of the holster to allow the Wave's pull-out lanyard port to pass through, for people like me who use a lanyard with their Wave.
  • The original holster had some slop that allowed the Wave to rattle around inside. I've therefore added some ridges to the back of the holster to produce a tighter fit. These ridges will wear down until they match your Wave.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes: Print this vertically, as it comes in the .STL. Have a look at the per-layer view in your slicer and how the infill appears before deciding to go with an infill percentage greater than 30%. 30% in PLA is already incredibly rigid. I suggest that you print this object with a brim. I use a brim that is 10 lines wide and 2 layers thick, which helps stabilise the object under fast print speeds.
As with all wearable prints, adding a radius to the edges and corners with a deburring tool, craft knife, or needle file is a good idea.

28 Dec 2017
  • The belt loop now accepts belts up to 45 mm wide.
    • 3 Sep 2017
  • I replaced the original remixed file with the newly-designed holster that I made for the Modular Leatherman Wave Holster project. The new holster is smaller, reinforced in the corners, and fits the Wave better.
  • Removed the 'remix' tag from this Thing because the STL is no longer a remix of CaptCanadaMan's Thing, but it is still linked in the body text.
    • 11 Oct 2015
  • Initial release.

description.text: This is the model M4A3E2 "Jumbo" Sherman, the beefed up version of the M4A3.  The print in the picture is decaled up as "Cobra King" which led the force that relieved Bastogne in the Battle of the Bulge.  I modified m_bergman's original M4A3 to add the extra glacis and side armor, and the thickened turret and wider tracks.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

15%

Notes: Printed hull with supports and no raft. Tracks can be printed with or without support. Print turret with raft and support.
Clean up with sanding sticks.  Assemble with CA glue.

Bergman's M4A3 modified in blender.  For the turret, I used the 76mm turret, along with a combination of scaling and boolean operations to make the thicker armor.  I also replaced the longer 76 mm gun with the shorter barreled 75 mm gun.
For the hull I created armor plates and used boolean ops to apply them to the hull.
I stretched the tracks to make them wider to match the actual tanks.
All in all it looked pretty good as printed, but I think the tracks and turret still need a little work.  I hope the photos do justice to the quality and detail of m_bergman's 1-100 models - they look great.

    • First, you will need to drill 4 small holes around the base of the prints, countersinking them after to hide the screws. After that, screw the hanger bolt inside the hole. You will the need to drill a small hole in the center of the dowels, making sure they are wide enough that your hanger bolt can fit in them. Then screw the connector to the dowel, making sure they align. Decide the best location for the legs on the table top and screw them into place. Place the desk in prime real estate in your home and enjoy your new workspace!

This is a simple fan mount/duct that takes up approx 3 PCI slots and provides a duct for a 120mm fan.  Attach the fan thru the holes using zip-ties.  Note that it may impede on the 4th PCI slot some, but it will fit okay if it's something that isn't too big.  Mine co-exists with a serial-backplate in the next PCI slot.
This part has support built in which I think should be sufficient on most printers.  It should be printed with the large, flat "bottom" facing down as shown with the purple render on the printing grid in my picture.
Depending on fan direction, this can be used as intake or exhaust.  I like to use it for intake and put a piece of filter over the back, so the fresh air is drawn in at the front (HD bay) and and back (PCI slot duct) which helps cool the expansion cards and such.  Dropped video card temps considerably having fresh air come in so close to the GPU fan.  Then all the hot air is exhausted out the CPU and PSU fans at the top of the case.

title: Dual E3D V6 mount for Prusa i3

description.text:
First ever Thingiverse design! It's a dual E3D V6 mount for a Bowden Prusa i3. It fits the standard X carriage with 30mm mounting holes (not the Rework carriage with 24mm holes).
I had been looking for a decent dual E3D mount for my P3Steel build, but after several days of searching I couldn't find one that suited my needs. All of them had their own specific issue: some were too big, some were too complex, some weren't adjustable for height, and some (surprisingly) had completely wrong mount dimensions and so couldn't clamp onto an E3D at all. So I finally decided to stop being lazy and designed my own.
This one I tried to keep as simple as I could while still maintaining easy height adjustment. Basically, I simply have 16mm holes to align the hotends and a hole+nut trap for a set screw to secure each of the hotends.
I also made a fan shroud (just to cool the heatsinks, no layer fan D:) that fits around both heatsinks when they're mounted.
It's the perfect solution for me. I won't claim that it's the perfect solution for anyone else, but if you are in a similar situation to what I was in it might be worth taking a look at.
I've also included the Inventor files so that if anyone wants to modify the files and happens to use Inventor, they can do so. 2016 and beyond only, but they're available for free for non-commercial uses through Autodesk educational community.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes: I printed with these settings, but it's not exactly critical. Just print with whatever settings you feel comfortable printing a strong part out of. You may have to scale it up or down 1-2% if your printer prints the 16mm holes too big or small. They should present a tight enough of a hold that the extruder can't be misaligned from vertical, but loose enough that it can twist and slide up and down.

Assembly Assembly is fairly straightforward. You will need:
5x 20mm M3 bolts (two for securing the mount to the carriage, three for securing the clamp to the mount)
2x 12mm M3 bolts (Set screws for the hotends)
7x M3 nuts or locknuts

  • Secure the part labeled "mount" to the carriage with 2 20mm bolts through the holes that run through the 16mm semicircle. If done properly no part of the bolt should protrude into the 16mm semicircle. I've included hexagonal holes for the nuts, but it doesn't matter which side the nut is on.

  • Secure the part labeled "clamp" to the mount with 3 20mm bolts through the two outer and one middle holes. The clamp should be secured just tight enough so that when the hotend is inserted, it can slide and rotate but not tilt.

  • Slide the hotends up through the bottom, and secure with the 12mm bolts through the holes facing the hotend.

Like many of us I have an EZ3D printer. Many have given up the fight to make the thing working good, but I keep updating the unit. I didn't like the fact that the PSU was separate from the actual printer unit. I have designed this holder to keep the Power Supply Unit attached to the bottom of the frame. That way the printer can be moved easier. There are two versions. One has a push in connector for the 8mm rod.
The second one has cutouts for ZIP ties to hold the 8mm rod. Both work and fit the frame. You will need M3 screws and 2 T-NUTS to attach the holder to the frame, You will also need at least 4 more M3 screws to attach the PSU to the holder itself. UPDATE: 10/28/15
I've just uploaded the new version of the PSU holder. This one has countersunk holes for the m3 bolts that hold your Power Supply, and I changed the bottom holes to SLOTS to allow some play fr the bolts. I've also added a side so it's a bit more sturdy... WARNING!!!
Be careful with your M3 screw length. I've used 10mm bolts with a m3 washer underneath. If your screw is too long you might short out the PSU!!!
Your chicks would play safe. Indoor mini pool and attached mobile

ok so for some reason on your system its not finding gettext. Could be based on where you have it installed, or where you're running it from...
You could try commenting it out and not get the error message translated at all.
The gettext() is doing language translation and if you're ok with english maybe you don't need it.
e.g. just remove gettext.gettext( and its closing bracket ) from that line (or any line using gettext)

Remixed agirgen's LED light ring into a light fork so that it would fit better in the area around my extruder.  Not entirely happy with the captured nut, it doesn't grab the nut I'm using very well.
The LED positions could also be a little better since the middle right LED is blocked by the heater cable.

LEDs If the holes are a tad big use a dab of super glue on each LED to keep them in place. http://ledcalculator.net/ I selected white LEDs from The LED Shop, Inc (on Amazon) and paired each with a 100 ohm current limiting resistor. Each LED / resistor pair was configured in parallel with the others and I connected the whole thing directly up to a 5v output on my PS. A switch and 300 ohm pot in series give me the ability to switch it on and off and also to dim it if necessary.
Remixing This is my first attempt at a remix. It was easy to import agirgen's original STL into tinkercad.

title: H4N Mic Stand Remix with Knobs

description.text:
Was frustrated that I didn't have the knobs and screws needed to finish the Project off as shown in the original post, so I edited the Mic Stand bracket to fit a 4MM-.7 x 25MM hex head screw from Home deport, and matching Nut. 
Then took the a SCAD (sorry can't find who to credit, and made knobs for the above screw, and then for a 1/4" thread x 3/4" Hex head screw to fit the H4N.  
I felt that the mount piece as originally designed, was a little thin, and when mounted to the Zoom, would warp a bit. So I thickened it up a bit, and you will find that here as well. 
Works pretty well. 
I haven't printed the thicker piece yet, but the other print OK.

Using my space truss module, creates a "platform" with user configurable length, width, and height. Automatically generates the (possibly hundreds of) cylindrical members and does all the trigonometry for you!
EDIT: Using changes to my space_truss() module suggested by qharley, the SpaceTrussBridge files have more diagonal members crossing in both directions.
I also removed a bunch of translate()'s from the sub-modules in the hopes of speeding up the program. Some are still necessary to move parts to the origin to rotate them because Openscad seem's to have ignore the v=[...] parameter in rotate( a=[...], v=[...] ), which would allow rotating around a specified origin instead of the default.

In the Openscad file: Only for the patient! Openscad takes a looooong time to render this. If you aren't patient, go do something that takes less time, like bake a cake under the hood of your car. If you have any ideas of how to make this easier for Openscad to process, I'm all ears! But just call truss_platform() with the length (x axis), width (y axis), height (z axis), and diameter of the cylindrical members. It seems to be faster to export it to STL and view that file with something else.

comments.text: You can reprint later ;-)
comments.author: zet23t

comments.text:
ABS is proving difficult. It keeps failing prints due to warping for prints with a base around > 6cm x 6cm. I have an improvised heated board that gets as hot as 70 degrees. Several prints have already failed due to warping: The print bends, the printer head collides and shifts and the rest is a mess. Small stuff comes out rather nicely. If it wasn't warping, I'd prefer ABS I think.
I have the same worries that getting ABS out might be a bit difficult, but I haven't tried yet. I only read that it's advised not to switch filament types because it can lead to jams. So I wasn't eager to test. I probably will find out.
comments.author: hackele

comments.text: I think PLA is more brittle than ABS. And for what I know ABS wants some 100-110 heatbed. Glowing iPhone will get some state-of-the-art-ness back ;-) In short, you should work to bring the state to the art realm ;-)
comments.author: zet23t

comments.text: Hm. I haven't noticed anything special about PLA and using it for a case. I have it now for one week and it doesn't show any sign of deterioration. Well, one segment's connector broke from tearing it off - the z-layer bonds aren't very strong in my prints.
comments.author: hackele

comments.text: For what I know (theoretically) PLA is more likely to break where ABS would bend a bit. That also means that ABS is more likely to absorb more shock once the phone falls down. Why do you need a case, BTW? To protect or just because it's metallic, cold and slippery?
comments.author: zet23t

comments.text:
Ah OK. well, should it drop, I'll know about it.
I made the case mostly for fun but to practice making things but also because I find the phone a bit small in my hands. And as I am often at playgrounds, my pockets are often full of sand grains and I wanted to have some separation of the phone and other surfaces. For former phones I had sand particles entering the microphone holes for instance. I suspect that the sand was just well enough pressed on the edges to find its way into the holes. I'd hope to prevent this from happening with this construction as well since there are larger gaps provided.
comments.author: hackele

title: Erlenmeyer flasks caps and pump holes
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I always wanted to create a liquid soap container that was not store bought.  
I bought some Erleynmeyer flasks and wanted to put a korktop. But korks are quite expensive to get and sometimes their size isnt ideal. So I thought that I can design one.  
So here we are, two different tops, each in two varieties. one whole and one with a pump hole for the liquid soap pump.  
the first is designed with a bottom diameter 31mm (a little bigger to accont for the ABS shrinking) and a top diameter of 36mm so it fits every flask with the same characteristics  
The second one has a bottom diameter of 22mm and a top of 35mm  
I also posted the freecad file so anyone can change the sizes. in the freecad file I also have a stand for the shperical flasks.

print your part and as it is still hot try to fit it in the flask. even small varations and shrinkage can make a cap unusable. adjust in freecad accordingly edit 13/7/13 I also made a cap for wide sized flasks, around 42mm diameter and experimented quite a lot with all sizes. The diameter of the erlenmeyer flasks is not so tightly adjusted so in the same brand and even in the same batch you can have a good fitting in some flasks while on others can be bigger or smaller. You can just mix and match and then print wider/narrower according to what you lack. A trick I found in order to counter that is to tap the cap on the flask while it is still hot. That way you ensure a nice fit, even though as it cools down it will shrink a bit more.
thats especially true with pla, as the pla tends to shrink more than the usual 1mm of the abs shrinkage

title: HeatBed for Replicator 2 and Makerbot Desktop v.3.7

description.text:
If we wish to add a heated bed in Makerbot Replicator 2 using new software Makerbot Desktop version 3.7.xx, the procedure it's a little bit different...
  • Stop background service from Makerware
  • Replace replicator2.json in folder: "C:\Program Files\MakerBot\MakerWare\Default_Configs\"
  • restart backgound service
    .
    Obviously backup old replicator.json file first...
    • I'm update to Makerbot Desktop 3.8 and working like a charm but.... make this modifications BEFORE update your custom presets with Update button in settings windows.
    If not theese presets will be overwrited with standard settings (without heat bed).
    I still don't understand why bed temperature not appare in monitor window during printing ... if someone have more info it will be apreciated

author: Smithyverse

description.text:
This surrounds and protects knots that you've made in pull-strings, lanyards, and so on. Also called lanyard nuts, cord stops, cord ends, or cord locks.
The part is 16 mm in diameter and 12 mm tall. The exit hole is about 5 mm, which is appropriate for a lanyard made from a doubled-up shoelace. You can, of course, drill or ream this hole to suit.
I've put some half-height posts around the inside edge of the cord end; these help retain the knot inside. It also means that you can fill the cord end with hot glue, which will form around those posts and lock everything in mechanically.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15

Deburr both sides of the exit hole before use.
You can fill this thing with hot glue to lock the lanyard/cord in permanently.

Why document the design process? Because there's a lot of resources on the net that tell you how to use design software, but fewer that actually show the process of design. Even write-ups for simple objects like this one would help new makers see what goes into a practical design. Sizing I measured my lanyard material (a shoelace) and found a doubled-over length of it to be about 4 mm wide, so my exit hole would be 5 mm to account for shrinkage since it's an internal hole. I wanted a chunky cord end for outdoor use, so even though a knot I made in the shoelace only came out to about 8 mm wide, I made the internal diameter 12 mm. The base shape I wanted to make something at least a little attractive, so I looked through Tinkercad's shape generators until I found Cog Ring 2 by Yoda Wars. The walls didn't need to be very thick, so I gave it an outer diameter of 14 mm to get 1 mm thick walls. Cog Ring 2 bulges out in the center, so the walls are thicker in places. I noticed that Cog Ring 2 has some funny faces at the top and bottom, so I flattened those faces by adding discs, which also serve an aesthetic role. Designing the exit hole I wanted the cord end to be soft against my wrist while I was using my lanyard, so using a flattened dome as the top face was an easy choice. However, just adding the dome to the top would have created a 90° overhang which would print roughly and potentially wear on the lanyard material. To design around this problem, I used a cone to cut a 45° angle into a 2 mm disc that I placed immediately underneath the dome. The entire top is therefore supported by an easily-printable 45° lead-up. Adding the posts I needed a way to prevent the end of the lanyard from fraying, and the solution was to hot-glue the knot inside the cord end to protect it. Hot glue would also add weight and rigidity to the cord end which is cool. However, I wanted the glue to have something to bite onto so that I would not only have a glued bond, but a mechanical one also. So I went back to my shape generators and found my best friend: Circular Array by lars busack. I set it up to make some posts half-buried in the walls of the part, and only half the internal height so that the hot glue would get above the posts and be unable to shift downwards.
• Initial release.

description.text:
This was inspired by "Paper Clip to set up simple photo background" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:95180 The curves of slepcat's design are a great idea, but I wanted to use heavier paper than the slots accommodated, and I wished the paper wouldn't come out of the slots so easily. I also wanted a sweep that could stand on its own with more stability.
Although not as elegant as the original, the stand in this design holds thin paper well and also allows for thicker sheets. The rear post helps support a higher background, and there is a plate behind the sweep that can be weighted for added stability.
Please see Instructions for assembly notes.

The file "Paper-Sweep-complete.stl" contains all the parts needed, laid out on a 175mm x 175mm bed, For printers with smaller beds, download the separate parts, printing the pin twice. The platens attach to the stands as shown using the the pins which go through the holes in the stands and are forced or glued into the receiving holes of the platens. Although most people find this works, there have been a few who've had the pins print out too small; if so, use 3/16" or M5 bolts & nuts.
To use, open the platen and feed the paper between the pivot and the stand. Holding the paper against the stand, close the platen and secure it under the hook on the stand.
The flat plates behind the curves are for weights which are needed for heavier paper. If you plan to use only one size of paper, clamping or gluing the stands to a stiff cardboard or foam-core board will make the setup easier and even more stable.

comments.text:
This is the first I've heard of this as a problem. Have you changed the scale in your slicing application?
You can also use bolts to hold the pieces together; use a second nut as a locknut to adjust the tension..

comments.text: I didn't change the scale originally, I am using Makerware.  I ended up scaling the pins up a little bit and used a dremel to make adjustments.  It works excellent.  Thanks for making this.

description.text: These containers are to place flowers and plants, which are coupled to the bicycle bar
